Numerical scheme¶

The code solves the forced advection-diffusion equation in one space dimension with vanishing Dirichlet boundary conditions (B.C. are hard-coded). The equation is discretized in time using is a semi-implicit scheme, combining an implicit scheme for the advection/diffusion terms (centered in both time and space) and a (explicit) leapfrog scheme for the source term.

Before discretization, the forced advection-diffusion equation is

\[\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} + w \frac{\partial u}{\partial z} = \kappa \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial z^2} - S(t,z,u),\]

where \(t, z\), and \(u\) are the time, space (vertical level), and the unknown (zonal wind), respectively, \(w\) and \(\kappa\) are the constant advection and diffusion coefficients, and \(S(t,z,u)\) is the source term.

After discretization, the equation can be written as

\[\left[ \mathbf{I} + \Delta t \left( w \mathbf{D1} - \kappa \mathbf{D2} \right) \right] \mathbf{u}^{\tau+1} = \left[ \mathbf{I} - \Delta t \left( w \mathbf{D1} - \kappa \mathbf{D2} \right) \right] \mathbf{u}^{\tau-1} - 2 \Delta t \mathbf{S}^{n},\]

where \(\Delta t\) is the time step, \(\mathbf{u}^{\tau} = (u^{\tau}_{1}, ..., u^{\tau}_{N})^{T}\) and \(\mathbf{S}^{\tau} = (S^{\tau}_{1}, ..., S^{\tau}_{N})^{T}\) are the vectorsof discretized unknown and source term at time step \(\tau\), \(\mathbf{I}\) is the \(N \times N\) identity, and \(\mathbf{D1}\) and \(\mathbf{D2}\) are the differentiation matrices for the first and second order derivatives defined here as

\begin{equation} D1_{ij} = \begin{cases} 0 &\text{for $i=1$, $1 \leq j \leq N$}, \\ (\delta_{i \, j+1} + \delta_{i \, j-1}) / 2 \Delta t &\text{for $1 < i < N$, $1 \leq j \leq N$}, \\ 0 &\text{for $i=N$, $1 \leq j \leq N$}, \end{cases} \end{equation}
\begin{equation} D2_{ij} = \begin{cases} 0 &\text{for $i=1$, $1 \leq j \leq N$}, \\ (\delta_{i \, j+1} - 2\delta_{i \, j} + \delta_{i \, j-1}) / \Delta t^2 & \text{for $1 < i < N$, $1 \leq j \leq N$}, \\ 0 &\text{for $i=N$, $1 \leq j \leq N$}. \end{cases} \end{equation}

The boundary conditions are implemented by: (1) Zeroing out the first and last rows of \(\mathbf{D1}\) and \(\mathbf{D2}\). (2) Zeroing out the first and last components of the source term. (3) Starting with a compatible initial condition vanishing at the boundaries. Note that (1) does not lead to singular matrices thanks to the identity. Finally, the matrix on the LHS side is constant and can be inverted only once.
